* Amazon AMI - to run in the [[Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud]] (EC2)
â
RPath has deals with [[VMware]] and [[Citrix Xen]] to make sure that rBuilder images are properly virtualized.<ref name="rooney" /> RPath ran only its own version of Linux until April 2008, when it made a deal with Novell to make a stripped down version of the [[Suse]] distribution that could be virtualized using RPath.<ref name="rooney">{{cite web | title = author = Paula Rooney | publisher = [[Zdnet]] rPath to OEM Novellâs SUSE Linux to reduce legal worries | date = 2008-04-22 | url = http://blogs.zdnet.com/open-source/?p=2321 }}</ref> In December 2008 it had also made deals to make versions of [[Ubuntu]] and [[CentOS]], but still has to reach an agreement to make the same with the [[Red Hat]] company, whose distributions have 60% of the Linux distro market share, because they refuse to sign the contractual agreement.<ref name="derringer"/> RPath's CEO expected that he would soon be able to optimize distributions like [[Debian]] and [[Fedora (operating system)|Fedora]] using RPath.<ref name="derringer">{{cite web | title = With Ubuntu and CentOS support, rPath spreads its wings | author = Pam Derringer | publisher = [[techtarget.com]] | date = 2008-12-01 | url = http://searchenterpriselinux.techtarget.com/news/article/0,289142,sid39_gci1340632,00.html }}</ref>
+
RPath has deals with [[VMware]] and [[Citrix Xen]] to make sure that rBuilder images are properly virtualized.<ref name="rooney" /> RPath ran only its own version of Linux until April 2008, when it made a deal with Novell to make a stripped down version of the [[Suse]] distribution that could be virtualized using RPath.<ref name="rooney">{{cite web | title = author = Paula Rooney | publisher = [[Zdnet]] rPath to OEM Novellâs SUSE Linux to reduce legal worries | date = 2008-04-22 | url = http://blogs.zdnet.com/open-source/?p=2321 }}</ref> In December 2008 it had also made deals to make versions of [[Ubuntu (operating system)Ubuntu]] and [[CentOS]], but still has to reach an agreement to make the same with the [[Red Hat]] company, whose distributions have 60% of the Linux distro market share, because they refuse to sign the contractual agreement.<ref name="derringer"/> RPath's CEO expected that he would soon be able to optimize distributions like [[Debian]] and [[Fedora (operating system)|Fedora]] using RPath.<ref name="derringer">{{cite web | title = With Ubuntu and CentOS support, rPath spreads its wings | author = Pam Derringer | publisher = [[techtarget.com]] | date = 2008-12-01 | url = http://searchenterpriselinux.techtarget.com/news/article/0,289142,sid39_gci1340632,00.html }}</ref>
